name: Dear Earth, It's Complicated: Sci560 Exhibition Walkthrough
description:
How often do we stop to smell flowers, hear birdsongs, or hug trees in Namma Garden City? Has it always been like this?

How has our relationship with the Earth changed over the past few decades? Where do we fall in its intricate web of life?

Join our mediators, Aslaha and Gaayatri for a guided walkthrough of the Sci560 exhibition, where we will reflect on our evolving connection with the Earth.

name: Specimens and Stories: A Visit to Natural History Collections

location.name: National Centre for Biological Sciences
location.address: National Centre for Biological Sciences, Bangalore

description:
How are specimens collected, preserved, and studied?

Join us at the Natural History Collections at NCBS and discover the fascinating world of specimens. This visit will be an opportunity to see how scientists collect, preserve, and study specimens that help us understand the story of our planet’s biodiversity. From pressed plants and drawers full of insects to preserved bird specimens, every item offers clues about biodiversity, evolution, and environmental change. Participants will also learn how these collections support research, education, and conservation, and hear the stories behind them.

name: Commons Across Scale and Space
description:
What do the landscape markers of Bangalore reveal about its people and their relationship with nature?

The territory of Bangalore is a complex composition of rocky outcrops, high grounds, flat lands and valleys. The process of occupation is premised on the idea of effective management of water and its associated infrastructure – both manmade and natural. The natural capacity of the land finds varied expressions in human use – from settlements to sacred groves, from seasonal and perennial agriculture to grasslands. Join Dr. Mohan Rao as he unpacks the complex mosaic of Bangalore’s landscape, where markers of culture and belief—both sacred and everyday—are deeply embedded. These layered terrains can be seen as ‘watermarked’ by human interaction, creating a powerful sense of place, belonging, and identity, and reflecting a longstanding relationship between society and nature.

This programme is in collaboration with Integrated Design.

name: What are the Commons?
description:
Are humans capable of sharing the commons?

Commons refers to shared resources that are not privately owned or managed by the government on behalf of a community. They transcend the urban and the rural and have become integral in today's environmental discourse. Join Amit Kurien and Rahul Paul as they unpack idea of the commons through engagement with private and state property, open access resources and the process of “commoning”. Explore why in this day and age why thinking about land, water, air - rural and urban - and even digital spaces such as the internet commons from the perspective of commons is integral if citizens are to take back control over resources that rightfully belong to them and to prevent exploitation in the current neoliberal world order.

This programme is in collaboration with Integrated Design.

name: Urban Commons: Ecology, Equity & Public Space
description:
How can we reimagine commons in rapidly urbanising cities ?

Urban commons—lakes, parks, housing collectives, and public spaces—are increasingly under pressure as cities grow. Join Anjali Karol Mohan, Sony Pellissery, Brinda Sastry, Sandhya Naidu, and Mohan Rao in a panel discussion that explores how we might rethink these shared spaces—from blue-green infrastructure and historic water systems to the governance of condominiums and the politics of public space design. Through diverse perspectives, the panel examines how collective stewardship, inclusive planning, and community-led design can help reimagine commons in ways that are ecologically sustainable, socially just, and deeply rooted in local context.

This programme is in collaboration with Integrated Design.

name: Study of the Commons
description:
How do we engage with the commons?

Join Kaustubh Rau and Nirmala Gowda as they take us through case studies of how engagement with the commons in the real world looks like. Through a documentation of the Tanks and Kaluves of Anekal, Kaustubh Rau will share insights from the work being done to preserve the Anekal wetlands. Nirmala Gowda explores how climate change policies affect commons. Tackling ideas of inclusive climate justice by looking at the drying of the Hemanthi river and hydropower projects in the western ghats.

This programme is in collaboration with Integrated Design.
